channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Issued Subpoena by Jan. 6 Panel, Setting Up Legal Battle
item.description: While the former president has suggested he might testify live before the committee, it was far more likely that the demand would lead to a legal fight.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump in Mesa, Ariz., last week. He released a lengthy, rambling letter that attacked the Jan. 6 committee’s work and reiterated false claims of widespread voting fraud but did not address whether he would comply with a subpoena.

item.title: Steve Bannon Sentenced to 4 Months in Prison for Contempt of Congress
item.description: Stephen Bannon was found guilty of two counts of contempt of Congress this summer for defying a subpoena from the House Jan. 6 committee.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon has used his daily internet radio show to skewer the government for prosecuting him.

item.title: Senator Graham Asks Supreme Court to Spare Him From Testifying in Georgia
item.description: Mr. Graham has been fighting a subpoena requiring him to appear before a special grand jury examining efforts to overturn former President Donald J. Trump’s election loss.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, has argued that the Constitution shields him from having to face a grand jury’s questions.

item.title: Ukrainians Brace for a Cold Winter Amid Russian Conflict
item.description: In cities and towns battered by the war, residents worry about how to heat their homes as temperatures drop. But even in places spared from the worst of the fighting, Russian strikes on infrastructure have raised new fears.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Federal Budget Deficit Fell to $1.4 Trillion as Pandemic Spending Eased
item.description: The gap between what the government borrows and what it spends narrowed amid less spending and higher tax receipts.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: President Biden said on Friday that the federal budget deficit fell to $1.4 trillion.

item.title: Here Are the 401(k) Contribution Limits for 2023
item.description: The I.R.S. announced one of its largest increases in decades to caps on retirement contributions, allowing workers with access to the plans to save more.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Internal Revenue Service will raise the limit on what Americans can contribute to tax-advantaged retirement accounts next year by nearly 10 percent.

item.title: Relentless Rise in Interest Rates Looms Over Another Volatile Week for Markets
item.description: The 10-year U.S. Treasury yield, which underpins everything from mortgages to credit cards, rose for a 12th consecutive week, matching the longest streak since 1984.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and Isabella Simonetti

item.title: Critics Say Katie Hobbs Has Run Too Subdued a Race Against Kari Lake
item.description: In the final weeks of a tight contest, critics say the Democrat, Katie Hobbs, has been too subdued. Her Republican rival, Kari Lake, a former TV news anchor, is taking full advantage.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: News crews followed Katie Hobbs, the Democratic candidate for governor of Arizona, last month on the campus of Arizona State University in Tempe.

item.title: In a Race Rife With Antisemitism Concerns, Mastriano Adviser Calls Shapiro ‘At Best a Secular Jew’
item.description: Mr. Mastriano, a far-right Republican who promotes Christian power and disdains the separation of church and state, has alarmed a broad swath of Pennsylvania’s Jewish community.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Doug Mastriano with Jenna Ellis in May, after Mr. Mastriano won the Republican nomination for governor in Pennsylvania.

item.title: Appeals Court Temporarily Halts Biden’s Student Debt Relief Plan
item.description: A federal appeals court temporarily halted President Biden’s debt relief plan, preventing the government from moving forward with the debt cancellation it had said could start as early as next week.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden speaking about student loan forgiveness at Delaware State University on Friday in Dover.

item.title: Biden Says 22 Million Americans Have Applied for Student Loan Debt Relief
item.description: President Biden accused Republicans of hypocrisy for trying to block the debt forgiveness.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden compared the student debt relief plan to the $2 trillion tax cuts that Republicans passed in 2017.

item.title: She’s Inheriting Millions. She Wants Her Wealth Taxed Away.
item.description: Marlene Engelhorn, 30, heir to a fortune, isn’t interested in philanthropy, believing it only perpetuates existing power dynamics. She’s calling for structural change to how the ultrarich are taxed.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy
item.media:credit: Mashid Mohadjerin for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The dream scenario is I get taxed,” said Ms. Engelhorn, the co-founder of a group called Tax Me Now.

item.title: Twitter Tries Calming Employees as Deal With Elon Musk Looms
item.description: With Mr. Musk’s $44 billion deal to buy Twitter set to close no later than Oct. 28, the company is trying to reassure workers about their employment and compensation.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. For months, the company’s 7,500 employees have worried how Elon Musk may change the service.

item.title: Teenager to Plead Guilty in Michigan School Shooting
item.description: The student is expected to plead guilty on Monday. The attack at Oxford High School killed four students.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at a vigil in memory of the victims of the Oxford High School shooting.

item.title: Lucy Simon, Singer and Broadway Composer, Dies at 82
item.description: She and her sister Carly Simon were a folk duo in the 1960s. Years later, she wrote the Tony-nominated music for “The Secret Garden.”
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: Lucy Simon in 1982. Her younger sister, Carly, became a best-selling pop star after their folk-duo days, and her older sister, Joanna, was an opera singer. Joanna died a day before Lucy’s death.

item.title: Joanna Simon, Opera Singer from Famously Musical Family, Dies at 85
item.description: A renowned mezzo-soprano, she grew up alongside her younger sisters, Carly and Lucy, both of whom became singer-songwriters.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: How George Clooney and Julia Roberts Quietly Became the Tracy-Hepburn of Our Time
item.description: “Ticket to Paradise” and other team-ups take advantage of their onscreen glamour and stellar chemistry and their offscreen affection for one another.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.media:description: They each bring movie-star qualities in addition to their onscreen chemistry.

item.title: Biden Just Clobbered China’s Chip Industry
item.description: The latest American trade restrictions could significantly set back China’s semiconductor ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo

item.title: Can Tim Ryan Pull Off the Biggest Upset of the Midterms in Ohio?
item.description: The Democrats are doing almost exactly what he said they should to save their political fortunes in the Midwest. But is it enough to win Ohio?
item.dc:creator: Alec MacGillis
item.media:credit: Megan Jelinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tim Ryan, the Democratic Senate nominee in Ohio, in Columbus this month. As manufacturing has declined in the state, so have Democratic fortunes.

item.title: Democrats Should Be Freaking Out a Little About South Texas
item.description: In this deep-blue area of a red state, the Republican Party is focusing on local races in a quest to transform the political landscape.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Verónica G. Cárdenas for The New York Times

item.title: What if We Let Majoritarian Democracy Take Root?
item.description: Majority rule is not perfect but rule by a narrow, reactionary minority is far worse.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: Notes on the Condition of Liberalism
item.description: The prospects for our present order’s renewal — or collapse.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

item.title: Finally, a Great Movie About Cancel Culture
item.description: Why we need films like “Tár.”
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph by Focus Features

item.title: Liz Truss and the Ruination of Britain
item.description: The Conservative Party has brought chaos to the country.
item.dc:creator: Peter Oborne

item.title: There’s Been a ‘Regime Change’ in How Democrats Think About Elections
item.description: Matt Yglesias breaks down the polls and helps take stock of this wild midterm election year.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump, pictured last week, released a rambling letter attacking the Jan. 6 committee.

item.title: Encore: A Lifetime of Good Loving
item.description: After 56 years of marriage, a widow finds hope for the future by remembering the sweetness of life spent together.

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: This weekend our TV critic recommends a gorgeous Italian drama, a naughty Australian teen show and a happy rom-com set in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.media:description: Luca Argentero, left, and Eduardo Scarpetta in a scene from “The Ignorant Angels.”

item.title: Your stories: Generational differences
item.description: We invited you to talk about your families and climate. Today, we’re sharing a few of the responses.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni

item.title: How a Prison Fire Unfolded in Iran
item.description: The cause of the fire last weekend remains unclear, but witnesses and families of prisoners say that the authorities had been bracing for unrest in the notorious Evin Prison in northern Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Wana News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: The aftermath of the Oct. 15 fire in Evin Prison, on Monday.

item.title: New York’s Gun Law, Already in Jeopardy, Is Dealt Another Blow
item.description: A judge temporarily blocked a ban on carrying firearms in houses of worship that was included in a state law passed after the Supreme Court struck down century-old restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:description: The Supreme Court left to lower courts many decisions about what areas could be declared off limits to firearms.

item.title: Cough Syrup: What We Know About Tainted Medicine from India
item.description: Tainted syrup from India may be connected to the deaths of dozens of children in Gambia, officials said. Indonesia banned cough syrup sales, though the link there is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: A notice at a pharmacy in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday announcing that the sale of medicinal syrup had been halted.

item.title: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s Ex-Leader, Is Barred From Office
item.description: The decision by Pakistan’s election commission is a major escalation of the showdown between the ruling establishment and Mr. Khan, and it raises the specter of unrest.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan in September outside a court in Islamabad.

item.title: Melatonin for Sleep: How the Aid Works
item.description: The “vampire hormone” can act like a dose of sunset, tricking your body into feeling like it’s time to sleep.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: The Best Exercises to Prevent Lower Back Pain
item.description: Back pain is common and complicated. But altering your workout to build control and stability can help prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Cole Barash for The New York Times

item.title: How A.D.H.D. Can Affect Your Relationships
item.description: The symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder can push couples to their breaking point, but there is hope for those willing to seek help.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: How Fermented Foods May Alter Your Microbiome and Improve Your Health
item.description: Foods like yogurt, kimchi, sauerkraut and kombucha increased the diversity of gut microbes and led to lower levels of inflammation.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
item.description: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Camille A. Brown’s Latest Dance Challenge? To Have Fun.
item.description: The busy choreographer returns to the stage, maybe for the last time, in her celebrated trilogy exploring Black life.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.category: For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf (Play)
item.media:credit: Elliott Jerome Brown Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Camille A. Brown, photographed at the Apollo Theater, where “ink” (2017), the final part of her trilogy, will be staged.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
